commentBody: As a retired Occupational Therapist, I enjoyed seeing 34D!

Pleasantly Thursday.

Took me a minute to figure out the gimmick, but the revealer revealed it, and knowing the gimmick was helpful to solve the rest of the puzzle.  Just the way it should be.

Also good cluing. I got tripped up at first in the northwest with airplane and then airLINER.  Also inventor.

Deb did not have to tell me that INVENTOR fits in 16A.  I'll add that WIDEBODY fits into 13A.  Between the two of them, I got off to a fairly slow start.

And I'll also mention that this is the kind of Thursday-tricky puzzle where I just saw that something odd was going on with the theme answers, but I didn't know exactly what.  By the time I saw the revealer (ORS) at the very end, I had pretty much completed everything without any idea why those theme answers were right.  So I just filled in the last three or four answers I needed, and then, jingle having played, I finally stopped to take measure of what was happening.

Moral of the story:  When you have a tricky puzzle where you have no idea why the theme answers are making no sense, just keep going.  Eventually, the revealer will show up to explain how it works.

One kvetch:  The word I know for "happiness" in Hebrew is "simcha" (◊©◊Ç÷¥◊û÷∞◊ó÷∏◊î).  Granted, I do not possess a deep knowledge of Hebrew vocabulary, but Google Translate tells me that in Hebrew, Sasson means....Sasson.  Is there anyone out there who is truly fluent in Hebrew to confirm or refute this clue?

After yesterday's Wednesday level Thursday, I was curious to see what the actual Thursday was, and found it to be a pleasant and brisk Schr√∂dinger-that-wasn't.

Nevertheless there's a decent amount of glue holding this one together. I think OWEITTO is simply painful to look at.

Potential double Natick in the NE. I follow politics pretty closely, so NED was pretty much a gimme, but Red, Jed, and Ted are all common first names. The jeans in question ceased to exist by the time I was born.

I've also never heard of a baby salmon called a SAMLET. I had hAMLET/hASSON when I completed the grid since I knew Hasson to be a real Hebrew word.

Couldn't find any other mistakes, so I brute forced until I got the crossing right and my Gold Star
Gonna be a rough NE corner for those not familiar with SASSON jeans.

Excellent grid but I struggled mightily nonetheless. I think I saw Simeon‚Äôs byline and it psyched me out - it shouldn‚Äôt have taken me as long as it did to finish. Besides, he‚Äôs broken our brains a lot worse than this.

This puzzle was certainly not ‚ÄúWaldorf/Dressed‚Äù.

On second thought, maybe all crossword puzzles are - WORD SALAD. In the best way - yummy.
Mostly fun Thursday. I didn‚Äôt love ‚ÄúOWEITTO‚Äù and I especially didn‚Äôt love ‚ÄúSAMLET.‚Äù That entire top right corner was a real hassle.

I haven‚Äôt read many  comments yet, but, I found this to be a wicked and fun little Thursday - All variety of misdirects and wordplay. 

The theme definitely helped me out in a big way - once I figured it out - And the revealer is the only way I would have had a chance at that. 

For my money, thats the best kind of tricky Thursday puzzle:

Solve the revealer -> crack the theme -> solve the puzzle.

In that order.

"That gold is mine! You'd better hand it over!"
"Ore what?"

(Get a lode of these puns.)
I really thought the theme was a letdown after the time it took to figure it out. I didn't really have an "aha!" moment, more like an "oh, that's it?" moment.
What is this, the Steve Convention?
What a slog. I'm still not sure what it was about --- and I'm not even gonna look.
Anyone else admit to having OFFERTO for 32A?
I oh so loved, loved, loved this wonderful puzzle with a cute theme üòòüòçü•∞
Oof. Can‚Äôt say I cared much for this one at all.
I do not understand EARNEDRUN for 30D?  Baseball reference?

Hmm, seems that some other initial comments are on two extremes, love/hate.  For me this was more down the middle.

It was serviceable.  But I found yesterday's Wednesday puzzle better built and more engaging in its theme and execution.  That is, more fun.  I was particularly unimpressed with the revealer clue today.  Again, serviceable, but not delightful.  Ah well.  To each his or her own.

this felt very similar to last thursday's gimmick which took some of the fun out of solving it but overall it was still enjoyable. That puzzle had mixed reviews so not surprised to see the same is true of this one.

(4th attempt)

Even the malodorous ump in 1A signaled this was a swing
and a miss.

I thought the theme was reasonably engaging. The cluing  seemed rather tortuous today so I‚Äôm grateful once I figured out the theme it helped me fill in the theme entries, because I needed every bit of help to fill in the rest.

The game ‚ÄúCentipede: Recharged‚Äù is made by Atari, Inc., a company that bought the assets of the old video game company. It's sold through Nintendo's online store because (like most video game consoles) a game can't run on the Switch if Nintendo doesn't approve it (and collect a fee).

I had a vague idea of what the theme was while I was working the puzzle - I saw the revealer and noticed that the theme answers all contained OR - but I didn't take time to fully understand it until I'd finished.  I find it fun and well executed even though I didn't need it to complete the puzzle.
On [Marquis name]. The only other marquises I can think of are Queensbury and Carabas. Any others out there?

I like this theme, even though I didn't understand it until I'd already completed the puzzle. 

Yes, it was similar to last Thursday's theme, but I liked this one better because A) I thought it was more clever to find two words that made sense together as one common phrase, rather than splitting up the two parts of the theme pairs, and B) The first part of each answer in this puzzle made sense, whereas, in last week's puzzle, the "instruction" part of the theme pairs was backwards. (RA TO UT should have meant you remove the RA from the second word and replace it with UT, but the solution was actually the reverse.)

I loved the clue for ER NURSES.

Loved the crossing of BOO with OLE. It makes me wonder if the constructor had been sitting on this one just waiting for the chance to use it in a puzzle.

For "Like looks from Mom and Dad" I thought of Disappointed, but that didn't fit.  (My teen years were challenging for all concerned.)

I'm wondering if there really needed to be a question mark in the "Marquis name" clue. I immediately thought DE SADE but waited to fill it in because the question mark made me think there was something trickier going on.

I am coming here in the middle of solving the puzzle to say that putting Shinzo ABE in this puzzle was rude and shocking.  As they say, "too soon" to put an assassinated person in a puzzle.  Better to have clued it to Abe Lincoln, though also assassinated, or the patriarch "Abe" Abraham, not assassinated.

Just finished the grid and read all of the comments. I thought the construction and theme were clever. Even better is @Andrzej and all of his comments tonight ü§£ I just woke up my husband after shaking with laughter from all of his emojis. Thank you for making my night, Andrzej ü§£ü§£ü§£

So, funny story, I started solving from the SE corner, filled in ORS from the crosses without ever clicking on or reading the clue, and so I never even saw the grid light up with the theme entries in yellow. (This is all before coffee.) Finished the puzzle still wondering how the theme clues related to the answers. 

A colleague teaches undergrads. His go-to saying after he‚Äôs had to answer questions that the students would‚Äôve answered themselves had they looked at the syllabus or done the assigned reading is: ‚ÄúAmazing [rhymes with whit] happens when you read.‚Äù 

Doesn‚Äôt it, though?

Over all, not too easy, not too hard‚Äîjust right for a Thursday. ERIEPA and ERNURSES just wouldn‚Äôt parse for me, and the penny took a minute to drop on the latter because I‚Äôve never heard the term EARNED RUN. (Great clue there, btw.) SAMLET for young salmon was new for me (luckily inferable), as was SASSON (thank you, newsfeed brain, for offering up NED Lamont from your dark recesses). PALOMA will always be the name of a song by Chavela Vargas to me, but the cocktail sounds really tasty. JPOP and BTS, thy names will always be ‚Äúcrossword fill I‚Äôve seen before.‚Äù

All in all, given the Simeon Seigel byline, we got off pretty SCOt free today. 

Have a good Thursday, everyone.
Great puzzle.  Rarely does it happen that I solve a puzzle, but I'm surprised I got it right and never even got the "trick" until I read the backstory.  Very enjoyable solve!

I guess this is not my week for figuring out the gimmicks. I didn‚Äôt get PARAS, what, was that on Tuesday? and I did not get today‚Äôs either. I was able to fill in the words, though. I will take solace remembering how much enjoyed yesterday‚Äôs. I love a rebus! Not so good with riddles.

I had no problem figuring out the theme, but SASSON crossing NED (and SCOW) felt mean to this particular 90s kid. Mashed my way through it, but I was so sure SAmSON would be the answer (a Hebrew name I‚Äôm aware of, at least!) that I convinced myself an m-COW was a crosswordese shorthand for a clunky vessel, i.e. a ‚ÄúMarine Cow‚Äù 

Also, ENOS vs ENOc will never not screw me up. I always assume some translations just drop the h in the more famous Biblical figure‚Äôs name.
OT's are not doctors.

Fun! 
If they somehow could have had the answer to 59A be OR NURSES it would have been a nice little homage to the rest of the puzzle.
I liked the theme, however not a fan of Sasson crossing Samlet and Ned. Also seemed like way too many 3 letter answers
Nice constructor notes.

"Baby"salmon? I haven't heard that expression, or SAMLET. They're fry, parr and smolts in these parts.
Not a fan of the theme, which felt a little laboured, but it sure helped with the solve, so no complaints.

Why the question mark on [Marquis name?]? It threw me off the obvious DE SADE for quite  a while.

As always, Simeon Seigel delivers a clever trick with just vague enough clues to keep things interesting.  

Excellent clues for ER NURSES at 59A and INHERITED at 14D.
I used to buy Sasson jeans and was sure they were manufactured by a Sephardic Jewish company. Surprised to learn that it's a Hebrew word.

Often I solve tricky puzzles without seeing what the gimmick is, or sometimes I figure the gimmick out without needing the revealer.  Today was neither of those days.  The revealer tipped me off that I needed to sprinkle some ORS in the themed answers, and those extra letters made an otherwise difficult seeming puzzle come together in a reasonable time.

HORNBLOWERS reminded me of the C. S. Forester books that I devoured in my youth.  They were a forerunner to the Patrick O‚ÄôBrian books i devoured in my adulthood.
Entered STOPS and OR NURSES, both correctly answering the clues. That plus an opaque theme left me flat. At least it's only one more week until the next Thursday puzzle.
A bit too twee for me‚Ä¶and no ‚Äúinvestment‚Äù  involved‚Äîinvesting makes one hope for a profitable outcome, not a trudge.

I seem to be logged in here, but not on the crossword page. It won't let me log in there and won't let me solve. 

And.. I submitted another comment here a while ago and it never showed up. Something weird is going on. 

Ah, well.

Boy, there was a day when I wouldn't have been stumped by a a cocktail name. But I just couldn't keep up with all that drinking when I got old, which I suppose was a good thing. Now I be all like, "What??"
A BEANO, by the way, is a feast in BrE, which gave its name to a children's comic.

from the crosses,
so I stared at the clue‚Ä¶
squinched my nose,
furrowed my brow,

Like sledding down a hill with my two

It‚Äôs gonna be a great day.
Every time I try to do the crossword, they just want me to change my subscription. Who do I contact about this?
Some tough fill and a theme I did not understand until near the end, this one took 20% longer than average.  A good Thursday workout.

Just over a year of doing the NYT crossword every day and starting to see the gold stars a bit more frequently. Getting familiar with some of the Americanisms and those funny recurring three letter words (nail varnish anyoneüòÑ). Today was a slog but I got there eventually so have that merry feeling of mild smugness to set me up for the day. Like others I struggled with the NE corner particularly samlet, Sasson and Ned but trial and error got me there in the end.

I liked this puzzle a lot. Useless trivia, some I knew, some I didn‚Äôt. A theme that I needed to solve for a few of the answers. And the long version of a 3-letter sports abbreviation! Hah, I got that one. 

And yesterday I was busy and missed my chance to bask in the thrill of knowing ALBATROSS. For the first time since high school (about 50 years ago!), being forced to read The Rime of the Ancient Mariner actually paid off. I remember almost nothing except the albatross being a PORTENT of doom. Another favorite answer from a recent puzzle.

Oy. For me the sequence was:

Step 1--solve puzzle faster than my average.
Step 2--come here to find out what the hell I did.

There were some very nice tricks, like the appearance of [Bell] in two clues, which happened to be totally unrelated, and the callback to my many hours spent in video ARCADEs in the early 80's. I would sometimes play Centipede, but my real favorites were Berserk ("Chicken, fight like a robot!") and the elusive Crazy Climber.

I know it's not up the coast, but my first guess for 31D was Elyria; then I got dooked by ERIEPA even after it was filled in.

Nice Thursday challenge.
This was quite a challenge. Getting the theme today was much more necessary than usual. I got tripped up a bit in the NE. A wonderful puzzle overall.

An extremely fine Thursday puzzle from Simeon Seigel today. Besides a clever theme, the clues were for me appropriately tough, so it took me a good while before the theme dawned on me. Once it did, the oceans of white space could finally get filled in. Very satisfying!

Puzzle as capital-P puzzle, where you work to crack a layered riddle.  

Masterful construction, with those crossing theme answers, and for me, going from empty to a full grid was a terrific ride, rich with brain-loving resistance and discovery.

But I just want to focus on one thing, because it‚Äôs a Seigel hallmark.

Yes, coming up with good theme answers takes much gruntwork ‚Äì scanning ‚Äú?OR?‚Äù words, finding phrases they start, coming up with examples of the second word that start with specific letters, and more.

Not easy.  Try it sometime. What Simeon did on that front was impressive enough.

But what blows me away is that he came up with this idea in the first place.  How did he do that?  How did he go from blankness to THIS THEME?

That‚Äôs what Simeon regularly does.  He‚Äôs a brilliant inventor.  It‚Äôs why I did a little inner leap when I saw his name atop the puzzle today.

So, thank you, Simeon, once again, for a fun and satisfying solve, and for another opportunity to experience your remarkable talent.  Bravo, sir!

Started in the SE and got the reveal right off.  Did that help figure out what was going on?  Not on yer life!  As usual I was overthinking the whole thing (almost) the whole time.  

Great fun and a nice challenge.  Many thanks.

Sheesh.

Boarded the wrong airliner, for sure!

Once I had the theme, I was able to complete my two unfinished thematic entries, leaving only the NW corner to reconcile. Having JUMBOJET and AIRLINER along with INVENTOR at various times made that corner a bit of a mess.

Solved this one unaided, but took me over 30 minutes. Despite the now obvious inclusion of OH after Cleveland, it took me much too long to get ERIEPA. 

A workout for me---this one felt a bit like a "themed Friday" puzzle. In any case, an excellently constructed puzzle (though OWEITTO made me wince).
I look forward all week to Thursday puzzles! Hats off to these clever constructors; I can't imagine being able to think up such intriguing ideas!
I'm with you, Deb, on Thursday puzzles. Sometimes they are impossible until they're not. Nice job, Simeon!

You put your foot down about something to stop it, right? And oR NURSES seemed fairly reasonable. Grrrr. I didn't hate this puzzle but it did frustrate the heck out of me!

Sometimes you know the date of something, like when a song was released, because you know where you were when you first heard it.

In this way, I am certain that "Centipede" was in the ARCADEs before 1981.  I am sure that I played it as an undergraduate, and I graduated in 1980.
Having said this, Wikipedia agrees with Deb that it was released in 1981.

Can anyone confirm my memory?  (Or do I need to increase my dosage of Ginkgo biloba?)

I found this quite challenging by Thursday standards‚Ä¶finished a couple minutes above my average‚Ä¶but I‚Äôm satisfied as I managed to plug away with no help, and I found so many of the clues clever: ‚ÄúThey try to admit the worst first, informally.‚Äù ‚ÄúForces offshore.‚Äù ‚ÄúSecured by a slip.‚Äù ‚ÄúKind of average.‚Äù

Congratulations to Simon Siegel for a first-rate crossword.

Am I the only one who remembers Sasson jeans? I was very young at the time, but I was a fashionable child. My designer jeans made me happy, although I had no idea they literally meant ‚Äúhappy‚Äù. I thought they were named for that Vidal hairdresser guy.

Speaking of happy, Happy Birthday to Simeon‚Äôs mom! üéà

Today's ear worm: "Ooh La La, SASSON!" Another walk down memory lane. Here's a lovely, nostalgic example, with stars of the 1979 NY Rangers, for extra nostalgic effect! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UilzHNm95Qg

That was a terrific puzzle! Well executed theme that I definitely used to get a grip all over the grid.

Erie, PA, being closer than CLeveland to the outlet of Lake Erie, is down the lake, not up, from Cleveland. Fortunately, I've seen this mistaken clue before, so I checked the crossings before deciding whether to enter Toledo, a better answer.

If the direction on a north-up map ruled, one would say Quebec is up the St. Lawrence River from Montreal. which it manifestly is not.
Difficult brain workout.  Had to really think. And that's a good thing.

Nothing comes between me and my Sassons.

(I will brooke no corrections.)

For two days in a row, I have been denied access to the daily crossword. I am a long-time subscriber! I have troubleshooted, changed my password, etc. All to no avail. What can I do to resolve this issue? Does anyone know?

I had ORS early on (Start at the Bottom!) and kind of skitttered around the grid, filling in HRE great OTTO I and the like.  Took a wrong turn thinking AUTocrat, AUTocracy.  Abandoned that for things like VERNE and ERIE, PA...  finally noticed the suspicious number of ORS in the puzzle, and that tipped the scales.

Fave:  HORNBLOWER.  As it happens, I'm nearly finished reading the CS Forester sea novels featuring Horatio HORNBLOWER (presently a comodore in the Baltic.)  My dad was introduced to the first novel --newly published _Beat to Quarters_--by a fellow mariner when he was in the Coast Guard.  (That novel's  success led Forester to write both prequels and sequels.)  Dad (b. 1912) saw more opportunity to advance in the Army and changed branches; he was in OCS when Pearl Harbor was attacked.    Quite different from the Aubrey-Maturin novels from O'Brian, but quick reads with interesting history....

After 30-plus years living and salmon fishing in Southeast Alaska, today I heard of ‚Äúsamlet‚Äù for the first time. Uncommon usage, but hey, it‚Äôs a Thursday crossword, so I‚Äôm good with that.

This was a tough puzzle for me, until suddenly, it wasn‚Äôt. I enjoyed it, I think!
Much too hard, with too obscure a theme. I made little progress on this one. Boo!
There are gimmicks and then there are gimmicks.  Too gimmicky for my brain today, more like a mental root canal.
I sigh every time a random sound is selected for a clue.  Always irritating those ones.  More so than obscure historical figures, since they can be so at random
I liked the theme a lot. It was quite fun once I caught on. However the fun was lost when I ended at the cross for SASSON / SAMLET. Those are two new additions to this solvers list.

I finished faster than my usual Thursday, but didn‚Äôt understand the answers until I read the column.  Not my favorite Thursday scheme, but once I figured out where the ORs went, it was straightforward for me.

Frustrating for me - culture differences, although I do try to remember US usage. 
SASSON was not in UK, nor DEEP with SIX, ER NURSE still doesn't  come to me easily, or REO, EREIPA, PORT AUTHORITY (we use HARBOUR) and the RUN. Had to look up SOS pad. 
 
I've never heard Covid referred to as RONA, always just Covid.

I fell foul, again, of the Latin plural - it's STERNUMS! 
Then the usual things I don't know, like CATERPILLAR and anything to do with musicals (OPERA CLOAK).

I carried on though, and got an amazing amount through the crossers and guessing, without knowing what the words referred to. 
After 51 minutes I had no idea of the theme either!
Still don't get WORMHOLES?

If you look up ‚Äúsamlet‚Äù in the Merriam Webster online dictionary, you find simply that it is a ‚Äúparr‚Äù. 

What is a parr? Well 3 of the definitions are:
- Called also samlet, skegger, and fingerling.
- A young leveret.
- A young salmon, younger than a smolt. 

And now I know.
In my opinion the plural answers WORMHOLES and SORESPOTS should have "and" clues instead of "or" clues, and therefore they do not belong in the theme set.

Fun and challenging! Took me 28m02s which really feels like I‚Äôm getting my money‚Äôs worth. 

Didn‚Äôt catch on to the trick til well into it but it helped the solve (in fact until I took a second look at ORS). For some reason I kept TORNBLOWER in there despite knowing it was supposed to be initials. 

Never heard SAMLET til today. Never heard of a PALOMA either. 

Good puzzle!

Here's Izaak Walton, in "The Compleat Angler" (1661 version), the chapter on salmon from my father's well-thumbed facsimile copy:

The Salmon is accounted the King of freshwater fish; and is ever bred in rivers relating to the sea, yet so high, or far from it, as admits of no tincture of salt, or brackishness. He is said to breed or cast his spawn, in most rivers, in the month of August: some say, that then they dig a hole or grave in a safe place in the gravel, and there place their eggs or spawn, after the melter has done his natural office, and then hide it most cunningly, and cover it over with gravel and stones; and then leave it to their Creator's protection, who, by a gentle heat which he infuses into that cold element, makes it brood, and beget life in the spawn, and to become SAMLETs early in the spring next following.

So, there was a theme? Okay. I did it on crosses and filled in the twee OMG, look these letters stand for clues!!! with logic. Okay, that's another Thursday in the can, completed to maintain my streak.

Unless "cousin" means three letter bit that might prefix to a last name, Van is not at all related to Mac or Ben; it is never used as "son of." The Dutch cousin would be "zoon," coming after the father's name, not before.

This was an IGIBIDGI for me (pronounced Idgy Bidgy).  It stands for "I got it but I don't get it."

I had to read Deb Amlen's explanation to get that there were four letters in each answer that read [X or Y] that made sense of the second part of the answer, and were the initials of the two parts of the clue.  

Really neat once it was explained to me!  Also kicking myself because I think I could have gotten it with a bit more thought.  

Kudos to the author for caring about details such as, not repeating any letters, and trying not to have OR appear in any non-theme answers.

I'm glad he didn't obsess over that.  A friend once told me "You have to learn when 'good enough' is good enough" and I stubbornly replied "It's good enough when it's perfect" to which he replied, "Fine, then spend 50% of your time getting it to 99% and the other 50% of your time getting it to 1% if you want."

Well when you put it that way...!!!

I really enjoyed the sleight-of-hand clues (admit the worst, etc).  Which of course I didn't get until I had at least half of the letters but these morsels gave me little bursts of dopamine when the penny dropped.

That was an odd theme for a Thursday, but I got my rebus fix yesterday, so I'm not even mad. I needed the revealer to finally get my head around what was going on. And after yesterday;s discussion, I was slightly disappointed that 8D was not PUNT.

Is JPOP making a comeback? I see that Shonen Knife will be touring this fall; I might have to go see them.
Stop with the cryptics! Read the Times of London if you want to do cryptics!
Fun puzzle; great Thursday! Thanks, Simeon Seigel!
Had to cheat to finish this one.I never saw or heard Covid-19 referred to as RONA. Is that an acronym?

Got about halfway though and just hit an absolute wall, confounded by the theme.  I had ORS from the crossings but no idea how to interpret it.  Got frustrated, took a break, came back an hour later and finished it up pretty much immediately, only struggling with the naticks at 7A.  Theme was suddenly crystal clear.  Sometimes your brain just isn‚Äôt the right gear, I guess!

Waaaaaaay over my usual time for a Thursday!

That's not a complaint; it's a compliment to the constructor.

(I'm just glad I didn't have much else going on at 6am....)

Solved in my usual Thursday time, even though today that included a few minutes of debate on whether it was SASSON or hASSON, which was my last letter. 

Figured out the theme when done. 

Although Deb indicates this type of theme has appeared in the last few weeks, it felt new to me. Not the OR part, but the fact that it was the first letter of each half of the hint that counted. That felt non-intuitive at first, and then, like all good themes, obvious. Somehow I had not noticed the position of the OR in each of the answers.

Don't think I've ever met a Thursday puzzle I didn't like, and my favorites are the ones with themes that surprise me. This one did that.

Yeah, on 57A... That's not technically right.

ABE Shinzo served as prime minister of Japan *twice* - his time in office was split.

@Monika Eckhart A key statistic for baseball pitchers is Earned Run Average, or ERA. The lower the ERA, the better the pitcher.

@Monika Eckhart Yes. It's the average number of earned runs a baseball pitcher would give up in a full game.  For 9 inning major league games with 3 outs per inning, it would equal: (# of earned runs given up) / [(# of outs recorded)/27]. So, for example giving up 1 earned run in 3 innings pitched gives: ERA = 1/(9/27) = 3.

@Jane Wheelaghan

A pitcher in baseball is trying to get the opposing team out without them scoring any runs.  His effectiveness is measured by how few earned runs--runs scored by the opposing team without any interfering misplays in the field (errors, usually)--he gives up per nine innings--the equivalent of one full game.

An earned run average of 3 is above average; 2 is excellent; 1 is a supreme achievement that only happens a few times in a decade.

"Gives up" is just another way of saying "are scored against him".  You can compare this to how many goals a soccer goalie allows.

@Beth in Greenbelt

Let me try to explain the infield fly rule in a way that will make sense to you. You have to see why it was created in the first place.

Normally, when a ball is popped up, the natural move is to catch it. The batter is out. This seems rather obvious, because that's a basic rule of baseball.

In the early days of baseball, someone clever realized that when there were fewer than two outs, and runners on first and second. or bases loaded,he could let the ball drop, and then get a double play. Since the runners could not run until the ball was caught, they were glued to their original bases.  

But once the ball hit the ground, they were subject to a force play. A quick-thinking infielder could throw the ball to third, and then to second before either runner could get there. (With bases loaded, there was a force at the plate, as well, so there could even be a triple play if there are no outs.)

The powers that be thought that this trick play made a travesty of the game. So they decided to make the infield fly rule to prevent it from happening.

Why no infield fly rule when there's only a man on first? After all, he and the batter are both subject to a force play. But the batter isn't stuck at home; he can run to first immediately, and would easily make it there. At best, the fielding team could just exchange one runner at first for another one.

Why no infield fly rule when there are two out?  Because there's no chance of a double play.

Logical, isn't it?

@Steve L

I think maybe you and I are in a minority because we see the perfect sense of the infield fly rule.

A fielder can't use the other rules of the game (such as not leaving the base until the fly ball is caught) to make an almost certain double play.

I always thought of that rule as the most brilliant of all of baseball, because it papered over a loophole formed by the other rules.
